unnormalised: ## Ditch the Netflix Binge: Why You Need to Hit Up a Film Festival, Yaar!
normalised: ## Ditch the Netflix Binge: Why You Need to Hit Up a Film Festival, Yaar!

unnormalised: Okay, let's be honest, we've all been there. Scrolling through Netflix at 11 PM, completely unable to decide between another episode of "Delhi Crime" or something…else. But listen, there's a whole world of cinematic awesomeness out there beyond your streaming queue, and it's waiting for you at a film festival!
normalised: Okay, let's be honest, we've all been there. Scrolling through Netflix at eleven P M, completely unable to decide between another episode of "Delhi Crime" or something…else. But listen, there's a whole world of cinematic awesomeness out there beyond your streaming queue, and it's waiting for you at a film festival!

unnormalised: Think of it as a delicious biryani of movies. You've got your familiar flavours, maybe even a screening of a classic like “Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge” at the IFFI (International Film Festival of India) in Goa. But you also get to try completely new and exciting dishes – indie flicks from Kerala, documentaries from Rajasthan, even short films made by your neighbour's cousin!

unnormalised: Film festivals aren’t just for serious film buffs with berets (though they're welcome too!). They're a fantastic way to discover hidden gems, support independent filmmakers, and maybe even rub shoulders with some cool people. Plus, imagine the Instagram stories! "Just saw this amazing film about a chaiwala who becomes a Bollywood star. No big deal." #FilmFestivalLife #GoaDiaries #IndieFilm

unnormalised: I remember catching a screening at the MAMI (Mumbai Film Festival) a few years back. It was a short film made by a student from FTII (Film and Television Institute of India), and it completely blew my mind. Totally different from anything you’d find on mainstream TV.
normalised: I remember catching a screening at the M A M I (Mumbai Film Festival) a few years back. It was a short film made by a student from F T I I (Film and Television Institute of India), and it completely blew my mind. Totally different from anything you’d find on mainstream T V.

unnormalised: And it's not just about the films. There are often Q&As with directors and actors, workshops, and after-parties. Who knows, you might even end up discussing cinematography over a plate of delicious vada pav with a future Anurag Kashyap! (Maybe bring a small bag of Rs. 50 notes just in case you want another one!)

unnormalised: So, ditch the usual weekend plan. Check out what film festivals are happening near you, book your tickets, and get ready to experience cinema like never before. Trust me, it's way more rewarding than watching another 3-hour movie marathon. And who knows, maybe you'll even discover your next favourite filmmaker. Maybe the next big thing is screening just 150 km away!
